title: Beyond Translation: LLM-Based Data Generation for Multilingual Fact-Checking
author: Yi-Ling Chung (Genaios Safe AI), Aurora Cobo (Genaios Safe AI), Pablo Serna (Genaios Safe AI), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) for generating multilingual datasets, which could inspire methods for audio-language alignment or assist in developing more robust models in my research area.
background: Generating multilingual datasets for fact-checking by creating synthetic claims based on factual knowledge sources from Wikipedia.
contribution: This paper introduces MultiSynFact, a pipeline for generating 2.2 million multilingual claim-source pairs to support automated fact-checking.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused mainly on English datasets or relied on translation tools, which often overlook cultural nuances.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines Wikipedia as a knowledge source with LLMs to generate high-quality multilingual fact-checking data, overcoming limitations found in existing methods.

key_innovation: The integration of external knowledge sources and rigorous validation steps to enhance the focus on multilingual claims significantly differentiates this approach.
real_world_impact: This framework can contribute to large-scale misinformation mitigation efforts across diverse languages by streamlining the creation of reliable datasets for various languages.
limitations: The generated claims rely on Wikipedia, which may introduce biases and inaccuracies inherent in the source material.

new_terms.MultiSynFact: **MultiSynFact** is a novel dataset introduced for multilingual fact-checking, leveraging LLMs for synthetic claim generation based on factual knowledge.

open_sourcing: The data and full implementation of the method are available at https://github.com/Genaios/MultiSynFact.
